We use Edsight the most for education related data. While a lot of info is available which is great, there is not the ability to cross tab the data by multiple demographics. And downloading the data to do this further analysis is slow and cumbersome. 
Also the college enrollment and college completion data is considerably lagging. 
Finally, it is unclear when each type of data is updated in the system so you have to just keep checking to see when the next year's data is there.

column32: (Geodata.ct.gov) Improve the data preview pages. The page that opens after a dataset is chosen. They don't work or are too slow. I would like to preview the data before downloading it instead of downloading it to see if the data will work for me.
column33: There needs to be better data descriptions and don't oversimplify data. I recently had trouble with the Soils Inland Wetlands layer in the Geodata.ct.gov data library. The field that distinguishes wetlands from non wetlands is CTInlWet. The attributes in the field are CT wetland and CT nonwetland. This field used to be broken down into the soil categories which is what I needed this updated data for. There is also no information on what the qualifications were for determining what is a wetland. The data.ct.gov has the same data, with a different date, and labels the wetlands the same way, but there is at least a description of the wetlands qualification.

column32: Right now, it is very challenging for academic researchers to link external administrative data with CT administrative data through P20WIN. The security requirements are always changing, the data elements in the online data dictionary do not match the data elements in the forms used by participating agencies, and the entire process is managed over email. More centralization (e.g. an online communications portal) and more standardization (e.g. a consistent data dictionary or standardized security guidelines) are essential for doing good research of policy relevance for CT stakeholders.

column11: Business analysis or other types of analytics;Link it with other data (e.g. administrative data);Developing plans or grant documents;Community outreach and engagement;
column32:
1) We need more data at the city, zip code, and census tract level.
2) We need more recent data, or data collected at regular intervals.  It seems hit or miss as to when agencies release their data, and how.  A static pdf may check the "we did it" box but it's not particularly useful.
3) Wherever the decision originated to use regional planning group geographies instead of county geographies, it is *not* appreciated.  Year over year comparisons of county data are now impossible. ????????????????????  
In my personal opinion, CT is backwards and wasteful for not using county government and county geographies for planning and admin purposes.  We should immediately go back to using counties as the default geography for Census and other data, and add RPG geographies as an optional view, just as Congressional Districts are.
Thank you.
column33: External users and government agencies would benefit from standardized, frequently updated data sets from both state and quasi agencies.  It's not rocket science to say that we could be making more efficient, impactful decisions if we did a better job of connecting, and using, the data we have.  That, of course, requires investing in staff, and CT continues to be stingy and shortsighted on that point.

In terms of Financial data at budget time municipalities are required to present and many times approve thier budgets BEFORE the state sets their final revenue numbers to the towns. column33: Please, oh please, include Jewish as a race or ethnicity. The Jewish Federation estimated that there are 20,000 Jewish people living in Greater New Haven alone. Statewide estimates put the Jewish population between 105,800-130,000. This is larger than many towns in the state. At a time when internationally recognized colleges and universities, including Yale, had antisemitic encampments and demonstrations on their campuses for months in 2023, it is critical to know how many people are at risk because of their actual or perceived Jewishness.

column9: The CT Open Data Portal (data.ct.gov);P20 WIN (Preschool through 20 Workforce Information Network);Directly from State Agencies or their organizational websites;From a non-governmental data or visualization service such as a web site or map that "scrapes" State data;
column10: Yes.  At the CT 359 Network, we have documented 20 years of data challenges among existing state data systems related to young children and their families in CT.  Most important is the state's inability to link unique child data (and information) with data about their families -- in real time  and across agencies.  This failure prevents effect care management and coordination at the individual level, improved accountability for spending and outcomes at the state level, and effective strategic planning at the state level.
column11: Developing plans or grant documents;Advocacy ;Link it with other data (e.g. administrative data);Policy planning, advocacy and accountability;
column32:
Concrete actions should be guided by the problems they seek to solve. 

In CT, we are missing children whose early development is at risk or delayed because we cannot employ real time data systems that link information about them and their families.  Each year, there are several thousand young children (and their families) caught in this circumstance.  These data on numbers of affected children are available from the UConn Center on Developmental Disabilities and the CT Medicaid Program. 

There are at least two concrete pathways to action that would enable improved care coordination on a child-by-child basis as well as aggregated, deidentified data for population and geographic analyses and quality improvement. Both require data to be accessible and in real time across state agencies. 

(a)	Craft legislative language requiring OPM and DAS BITS to propose a technology solution plan for unique child and family data connections in real time (on a statewide basis or pilot basis) potentially  using state- licensed commercial technology. A report back to the legislature by early fall 2025 would be required. The precedent for this pathway was set in 2023 and 2024 through the following legislation:  (PA 24-45 Sec. 21(b)  -- data integration for older disconnect youth-- and PA 23-137 Sec. 13  -- for persons with an intellectual or developmental disability.  While a viable pathway, this is probably not the best answer in that it produces reports but no action. 

(b)	Propose a two-city pilot, including New Haven as one site with another to be identified (Hartford or perhaps Norwich) to test a  commercial technology “network solution” to find, match and identify practice, policy and fiscal issues in real time connectivity. This pathway is offered in lieu of a similar proposal to just solve the problem once and on a statewide basis.
column33: Because children and families live in communities and not in state agencies, local communities have been trying to solve these problems literally for two decades.  We have identified at least 10 service improvement efforts that are disconnected from knowledge sharing -- and data development progress.  You could pull these efforts forward so we can learn how each is addressing the problem(s) identified above.

column32: Serve as not only a hub for the state's data but also for municipalities' data. I have a reason for suggesting this. Connecticut is carved unnecessarily into town and city level jurisdictions that collectively aren't well equipped to handle some of the contemporary functions of regional (local) government. I've lived and worked in a few states over the past 25 years and this struck me as apparent immediately upon moving here with my family almost 3 years ago. One way the state can help is to pick a few of those responsibilities up. Data collection, standardization and public accessibility is one of the obvious functions. The state already does at least a little of this via statewide land and parcel data, but the potential is bigger.

column11: Business analysis or other types of analytics;
column32:
I work for a national nonprofit consulting with states, counties, and resource and referral networks in the child care space.  I'm currently working in a handful of states assisting them with data interoperability between internal systems and API connections from external systems to achieve near-real-time data sharing.  I've entered my info below on this form for a follow up conversation, but to quickly put a few things out:
- Access appears to be very good.
- Interoperability is the big one.  What I see is that a common ID between systems is a very big challenge requiring a data owner.  Without the interoperability piece working well, it will force users to have to download each data set and then try to connect them when doing any analytics work.
-- Common Applications between multiple state departments, connected internal systems (lot of data alignment work needed here), reviewing currently collected information with the goal of minimizing the amount of entries users must make, feeding information in real-time to centralized databases (ODS, Data Lake, etc) for more reporting flexibility, policy alignment between departments and policy reduction where possible (Is this how it's always been?  If so, can we update this to reduce overhead?), linking back into the state any augmented data
- No concerns on security.
- Quality of data looked good, but a lot of the reports looked older and I couldn't find a way to download historical data sets to see trends over time.  (Just started looking at the system though)
column33: I'd like more information on the advisory board.  What does that entail and what type of people are you looking for to sit in those roles?  I'm located in West Hartford CT and my contact information included below.  Thank you!
